story:
Long story short, I have too much debt and not enough income. I took out one pay day loan which turned into multiple pay day loans which turned into the majority of my paycheck going to paying these loans with little to no money left to pay my rent and bills. It has been getting gradually worse for months until I reached the point I'm at now where I need assistance outside of my family and getting more loans. I have already started the process for consolidating these loans. Unfortunately, I do not have any money left over to pay my monthly bills.

At this point, March's rent is already late and will get to the lockout/eviction status on the 11th. I owe $191.21 for January's car note. If that is not paid ASAP, my car will be repossessed. I only have one more payment left on the Pimpala before she is paid off. This is the most important bill besides rent.

I am also behind on the light bill which is scheduled for disconnection any day now. I also owe for last month's Comcast internet bill, but that is irrelevant if the power is disconnected.

I wouldn't ask for assistance if I didn't really need it and if I had not exhausted all other possible options first. I don't know if I can repay anyone that helps other than my gratitude and some baked goods. Mr. Grey and I would appreciate any help you can offer.

story:
Short Summary

Hello everyone! My name is Albin and I've got a shoutout!

My father Jon Ernholm is currently working as an volunteer in a village called Tengeru in Tanzania where he is stationed at a government hospital called Meru District Hospital, it has very limited resources and regarding aftercare almost none.

He has a background as a massage therapist and he's trying to create a way to practice and to teach the physicians these therapies, so as to give the hospital a way to provide Physiotherapy and Massage therapy aftercare which is currently almost non-existent.

What We Need

So what's needed for this to become a reality is firstly a place to be!

So the plan is to firstly buy one canvas tent to use as a space for the therapies, and if there is room in the funding to buy a second so as to be able to hold separate treatments.

Also there's need to make some ground and electrical preparations for the tent.

And then it's furnishings and material such as a desk, stools, shelves, benches, oils and scrubs etc.

And material to make a sun and rainproof waiting booth.

The Impact

Since there is near as no aftercare at all for the people who do not have money to visit the private hospitals, which is pretty much most of them, this is a measure that's really needed for people who has sustained physical trauma and other trauma alike

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help spread this around amongst your friends!

Every bit counts!

Love to you all!

Mount Meru

                                                      Outside the hospital

story:
Please help use help this cause.

          I, along with other work colleagues are putting together team "REBEL" whom will be competing in the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation "2015 Sports Challenge", which is a mini Olympic-style Competition, where 10-person teams from corporations, businesses and professional groups compete against each other in a series of fun, athletic events. Held on:           

                                        

             Saturday, April 4, 2015 7:30 am - 12:00 pm
                                 Metlife Stadium
             1 Metlife Stadium  East Rutherford, NJ 07073

Money raise is to help pay for the enrollment fee of $400 per person.

I've put together two 10 person teams. Hens the $8000.00

The teams consist of members of the "International Carpenters Union Local 254"

Further Info:

http://newjersey.cff.org/sportschallenge

What is CF ???

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a genetic disease affecting approximately 30,000 children and adults in the United States. A defective gene causes the body to produce an abnormally thick sticky mucus that leads to chronic and fatal lung infections and impairs digestion. 

Currently, there is no cure. Scientists are now developing several new clinical approaches to treating CF, which look very promising.

Our challenge is to raise the dollars through events such as Sports Challenge, to support the mission of the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, and help give the children and adults with CF, the quality of life and future they deserve.

story:
ABOUT "APRICOT"

Even though much of the visible debris from the earthquake, tsunami and nuclear accident of March 2011 has been cleared away, there are still tender wounds remaining in the hearts and minds of many children and their families in Japan's Tohoku region. Whole family units, neighborhoods and entire communities were devastated by the event. This has forced hundreds of thousands of children, mothers and their families to live in temporary housing units. Among these are the more than 71,000 children and mothers who have been evacuated from Fukushima Prefecture's eastern districts. They have been scattered throughout Japan, many living separated from their fathers, grandparents and friends. In such unstable, impermanent and stressful circumstances children can be especially susceptible to intense anxiety, depression and in time PTSD (Post Traumatic Stress Syndrome), the symptoms of which can take many years to manifest. Recent government surveys suggest 1 in 3 children in Tohoku are already suffering from mental health issues.

APRICOT (Allied Psychotherapy Relief Initiative for the Children of Tohoku) is an officially registered NPO 法人 supporting the ongoing efforts of Japan's mental health professionals working directly in the Tohoku Region to provide counseling relief services for children and their families who have been affected by the triple disasters. Our mission is to raise awareness and funding so these children and their families can receive the long-term mental health care they will need to ensure Tohoku recovers.

APRICOT is a 100% voluntary project, comprised of experienced Japanese and non-Japanese mental health professionals, as well as people from backgrounds as diverse as finance, business and media. Being 100% volunteer run, we don't take salaries. We don't take expenses. We do take all the goodwill and help we can get. All funds raised by APRICOT go to registered mental health NPOs and other well-vetted organizations working in Tohoku to be used to support the mental health of children in the region. Recipient organizations include the disaster relief mental health committees of the Japan Society of Certified Clinical Psychologists (JSCCP) and Fukushima Society of Certified Clinical Psychologists (FSCPP). If you would like to see examples of how funds have been allocated previously, please have a look at our 2013 report.

Much still needs to be done in Tohoku both now and over the long term. The work of mental health professionals in the Tohoku region is aimed at healing and, as far as possible, preventing the onset of anxiety disorders, depression, PTSD and other illnesses that can develop in children during both short-term and long-term life events. APRICOT is a movement dedicated to ensuring that children in Tohoku will have the support they need until each and every one of them reaches adulthood.

story:
Short Summary

I'm not young researcher, almost 60, but I always look for new ideas to realize. I was, in my past lives, artificial intelligence researcher and I never stopped to search for new projects, thinking that a project is important if it could give some real advantage to people. Now I'm involved in telemedicine device development and I found that there is little about remote rehab. 

So, while I'm developing an open source device able to monitor a lot of parameters about health state of the patient and to send them to expert people that will evaluate health state, I'm also looking for a new device, a new sensor, able too give to the remote expert some real measure about a rehab path.

The idea is to send electromyography values while muscle is doing known work opposing to a mechanical known force, force that is produced by the sensor itself and that can controlled in an exact way from an electric signal, i.e. from the local control device or from remote expert through some specific commands to local control unit.

In other words, the sensor is composed by two different devices: one, standard, able to do EMG (and this one will be one of the open source proposals available on the Web). The other device, that is the real new device, is a device able to produce a force, to say applied on a lever, of well known intensity, intensity that can be varied by electronic circuit.

Why this sensor? Because it will help a lot of people, young or elder, to rehab staying at home, having their trend monitored by an expert from remote. A lot of saved money, better home assistance, good opportunity in all that cases when it would be impossible to have an expert near the patient.

Obviously, after the device will have built, we will need a lot of testing with physicians monitoring. But, anyway, a little step toward a new solution will have been done. Mainly thank to your contribution.

What We Need & What You Get

The amount of money I ask for is that needed to:

  1. buy the stuff we need: arduino boards, electronic muscles, mechanical parts, precision tools to tune the system, i.e. all the stuff needed to make tests and refine the basic project idea;
  2. involve expert of Android apps to develop the software to control from remote the device and to transmit EMG data;
  3. build at least three or more devices to give them to experts that can test them and help us to make the final device, the one that can really help people in their rehab path.
I am sure that you all will help me in this project but, anyway, if I will have not been able to explain my project with my awful english, and the funding will not reach the amount of money I ask for, I will resize the project so to obtain anyway a result to propose to expert physicians, maybe less good but enough, I hope, to promote the idea.
The Impact

Your help could mean to develop the project in a short time (at the moment I think 6/9 months). The relevance of the project is the idea of developing some device able to support rehab whose costs are low. An open source device around which communities can develop new solutions, opposing the market proposals of the big companies proposing expensive solutions.

Think of how many people need rehab for diseases or after a crash. Think how much better could be if only half of them could shorten their hospitalization thank this new device. Think also of workers that are far from any health structure that could be supported in their rehab after an accident.

I think that the amount of money is really little compared with benefits that such a cheap device could have in the real world.

This little project could help to rehab people in their home. The first step, it's true, but the demonstration of an idea.

This project wants to be open and cheap because it wants to be used by a great number of people and improved also with communities ideas.

Not a new expensive device for few people but a low cost device for all, a new approach in the eHealth.

Risks & Challenges

The project has not great difficulties. It only needs the right stuff to work with, the time to tune exactly all the components and the production of a detailed plan so to make easy to rebuild it for anyone that would like to work on it.

Other Ways You Can Help

Any help, also ih the app development, will be nice... very nice.

story:
Have you ever laughed so hard a tear ran down your...leg? 

One in three women suffer from incontinence after having their babies. Many of them either laugh it off because they think it is normal and everyone they know has the same problem or they are embarrassed by it. Pelvic floor dysfunction can present itself in many ways, from incontinence to knee pain to painful sex.

But, it doesn’t have to be that way. 

Cara Turnquist has been a personal trainer for over 15 years, and during that time it has been her life’s mission to open a women’s center that brought together professionals from different disciplines to offer holistic care to women in her community. When she met personal trainer Jill McLean seven years ago they developed a friendship and eventually a business, and it was clear that they shared the same vision. The two of them put a plan in motion to help women feel strong and empowered on the inside and out! 

Together they run Movement Duets, a personal training business that specializes in pre and postnatal fitness. They work with women of all ages to build strength while honoring their symptoms and the transitional phase that their body is in. 

Over the next few months they will be joining forces with the Physical Therapists of The Pelvic Wellness Center, the PNW Doulas and several other women-owned, women-centered businesses to offer the women of Salem, OR a haven of health and fitness that has never before been available. They will continue to help women have more comfortable pregnancies, heal their ab separation, stop peeing when they cough, have better sex and more. 

“I’m just about the only mom in my bootcamp class who doesn’t have to run to the bathroom during burpees!” says a newly postpartum Movement Duets client of one year.

We want to keep having success stories like these. And with your help, we can. 

Please donate and help them keep their business alive and fulfill their dream. Help them help and empower women in our community. Having a child should not keep women from fulfilling their dreams and living their biggest lives! Your money will not just go towards the purchase of gym equipment, it will go towards helping women feel strong and proud in their changing bodies. Imagine what could happen if more women in our community felt that way?

story:
In Brief

 

The Achon Uganda Children’s Fund aims to expand its charitable efforts in the village of Awake, Uganda by building a medical clinic. The clinic will bring affordable, basic health care to residents for the first time, as the closest medical facility is currently located 42 miles away. Of the $90,000 that is necessary to finance the clinic, $52,000 has already been raised, leaving the clinic $38,000 shy of breaking ground. Your financial support would be greatly appreciated to help provide medical supplies, construction, and staffing. 

 

Julius’s Story

 

In 1988, a band of militant rebels abducted a twelve-year-old boy, named Julius Achon, from his home in rural Uganda. They repeatedly drugged the child and forced him to fight alongside other kidnapped youth. Unlike many others, this particular boy managed to escape. He went on to earn a track and field scholarship at George Mason University, where this boy from one of the most destitute regions of Africa matured into a world-class athlete. In 1996, Julius competed in his first Olympic games, an honor that earned again four years later.  As awe-inspiring as this heroic tale may be, Julius’s inspirational story had only begun.

 

In 2003, Julius returned to the village of Awake, Uganda, where he came across eleven orphan boys living under a bus who were fleeing from the Lord’s Resistance Army - just as he was 15 years prior. Julius adopted all eleven children, whom he supported with food, clothing, shelter, and school tuition, using at first only his modest salary from endorsements. He was eventually able to establish the Achon Uganda Children’s Fund, which raises money to help assure the homeless children of Awake the same potential that Julius was able to achieve. Julius’s support has been integral to the Awake village, establishing a community center, a pit latrine, and a permanent well that provides the first sources of clean water to the village less than three miles away.

 

The Kristina Acuma Achon Clinic

 

The Achon Uganda Children’s Fund has recently embarked upon their largest endeavor yet - a medical clinic that will provide care for the residents of Otuke County. The facility will be erected in honor of Juilus’s mother, Kristina, who was shot by the Lord’s Resistance Army and died from wounds that may have been treated had the closest medical facility been less than 42 miles away. The clinic will provide primary medical care, including triage and appropriate treatment, disease testing, inoculation, medication dispensing, and community outreach. The staff will comprise Ugandan MDs and RNs as well as a general manager and staff, augmented by periodic visits from US-based doctors and nurses. Plans are underway to establish extensive partnerships to create a set of best practices for developing access to appropriate medical care in rural Africa with the likes of Ugandan Ministry of Health, Engeye Clinic, Uganda Cares (HIS/AIDs testing), Lifewater International, Medical Teams International, and other local and international aid organizations.

 

The Achon Uganda Children’s Fund and Love Mercy have already raised $52,000 for the construction of the clinic, but another $38,000 is needed to actualize the project. The money that is donated towards this clinic will go towards medical supplies, building materials, construction, and staffing, which will provide locals with access to affordable, basic medical care for the first time in their lives. Julius was able to overcome the hardship of being a child in this warn-torn community, and he has returned to help others in dire need. Please consider lending your support so that other children in his position may one day do the same.           

 

Current Status of the Clinic

 

- A 60 by 80 meter property in the village of Awake has been purchased, which will house two primary buildings – the medical clinic and staff living quarters. Preliminary architectural drawings have been completed, modeled after the Engeye Clinic, which was built near Masaka, Uganda in 2007.

- Village residents and village elder council members granted enthusiastic approval for the clinic in November 2010

- Achon Uganda Children’s Fund and Love Mercy have raised $52,000 of the $90,000 necessary to fund clinic construction, leaving an addition $38,000 that still needs to be funded.

 

Who Am I?

 

My name is Roger Batt. I am a recent graduated from Harvard College, where I studied Neurobiology and History of Art and Architecture. As a pre-medical student, I became interested in helping children from underprivileged communities, which led to involvement with projects such as Harvard China Care and the Mission Hill After School Program in Boston. I became aware of Julius’s inspirational work after speaking with staff at the Engeye Clinic in Uganda, and I feel privileged to become a part of this worthy cause. I am asking you to help me help Julius with his very noble, and very necessary, endeavor by donating whatever you can to help.                       

 

For further information, please visit achonugandachildren.org

US-based doctors and nurses. Plans are underway to establish extensive
partnerships to create a set of best practices for developing access to appropriate
medical care in rural Africa with the likes of Ugandan Ministry of Health,
Engeye Clinic, Uganda Cares (HIS/AIDs testing), Lifewater International,
Medical Teams International, and other local and international aid
organizations. 

 

The Achon Uganda Children’s Fund and Love Mercy have already
raised $52,000 for the construction of the clinic, but another $38,000 is
needed to actualize the project. The money that is donated towards this clinic
will go towards medical supplies, building materials, construction, and
staffing, which will provide locals with access to affordable, basic medical
care for the first time in their lives. Julius was able to overcome the
hardship of being a child in this warn-torn community, and he has returned to
help others in dire need. Please consider lending your support so that other
children in his position may one day do the same.            

 

Current Status of the Clinic
 

- A 60 by 80 meter property in the village of Awake has been
purchased, which will house two primary buildings – the medical clinic and
staff living quarters. Preliminary architectural drawings have been completed,
modeled after the Engeye Clinic, which was built near Masaka, Uganda in 2007.

- Village residents and village elder council members
granted enthusiastic approval for the clinic in November 2010

- Achon Uganda Children’s Fund and Love Mercy have raised
$52,000 of the $90,000 necessary to fund clinic construction, leaving an
addition $38,000 that still needs to be funded.

 

Who Am I?

 

My name is Roger Batt. I am a recent graduated from Harvard
College, where I studied Neurobiology and History of Art and Architecture. As a
pre-medical student, I became interested in helping children from
underprivileged communities, which led to involvement with projects such as
Harvard China Care and the Mission Hill After School Program in Boston. I
became aware of Julius’s inspirational work after speaking with staff at the
Engeye Clinic in Uganda, and I feel privileged to become a part of this worthy
cause. I am asking you to help me help Julius with his very noble, and very
necessary, endeavor by donating whatever you can to help.                        

 

For further information, please visit
achonugandachildren.org

story:
My sister has been diagnosed with mitochondrial myopathy, an incurable muscle disease that the doctors at the Mayo Clinic in Jacksonville, FL has said there is no cure or treatment for.  My sister worked up until early 2012, when doctors said she'd be no longer able to work again.  Her job ended as well as all medical benefits.

She has to be seen by neurologists as well as cardiologists on a regular basis.  This disease can affect every organ in the body.  My sister needs help with donations in order to pay her medical expenses and medication.  My sister lives with our elderly parents and they are on a fixed income trying to keep their household going as well as keeping her needs met as best they can.  Thank you for your help!

story:
Light for Lily...….a story of love and sacrifice, for love is sacrificial or it is not love at all.

“Eating is a learned behavior, not an instinct after the first few weeks of life.” – Dr. Kay Toomey

As parents, we must constantly feed our children. For most of us, this isn’t a problem because our children have instinctively learned to eat. Now imagine if your child never learned to eat, that hunger was never a feeling, that food and water was something foreign, that swallowing was painful marred by choking, retching, gagging and vomiting. 

“Toddlers don’t eat when it hurts to eat and they are afraid it will hurt to eat.” – Dr. Paul Hyman

From her premature birth, Lily Colonnese, the only daughter of my good friends Gary and Diane,  has dealt with over 20 diagnoses of disease and illness. The most difficult and challenging one has been learning to eat. Born a “preemie” at 27 weeks on September 15, 2003, Lily was 1 lb. 6 oz. and 11 inches long, very small and very sick. She was in the NICU for 122 days and mostly on the ventilator to keep her airway open and breathing. Acid reflux was the villain. It burned her airway, her throat, her vocal cords and her lungs. Between the horrible reflux and the invasive ventilator, Lily never learned to suck or swallow and therefore, never learned to eat. She has been on a feeding tube her entire life.

Lily has dealt with severe trauma and sensory issues from multiple hospitalizations, invasive testing, countless therapy sessions, far too many doctors poking and prying, and she has been unable to interact with her environment like other children. Her immune system and airway have always been severely compromised and frail.  However, through much sacrifice and many miracles along the way, Lily is learning to eat. This is where she needs your love and support.

Gary and Diane have borne the emotional, psychological and financial burden of caring for Lily and providing all the resources necessary for her well-being. They have literally chased therapy all over the country. Gary works extremely hard to provide for his family. Diane provides constant, 24-hour a day, care for Lily and is therefore, unable to work outside of the home. From 2007 through 2012, they lived separate lives so Gary could remain employed and provide the financial support and health insurance for Lily. Diane took care of Lily’s health and safety as they travelled around the country seeking help. This made an extremely difficult situation even more painful.

Gary and Diane have accumulated great debt since health insurance covers only a fraction of Lily’s medical costs-which will run as high as $40,000 annually. They have lost their home, their life savings, their 401K’s and have to live paycheck to paycheck to make ends meet. They have willingly sacrificed everything for Lily and will continue to do so because Lily is worth it. She has lived to tell her story and what a story it is.

In 2012, the family relocated to Dallas to work with the great medical community and therapy programs available there. Recently Lily re-entered an intensive, 30-day inpatient feeding program to help her continue to learn how to eat. However with major outpatient therapy still required for the next year, and a daily intensive feeding regimen, the medical expenses remain overwhelming.

In our country, feeding issues are grossly misunderstood and underserved. Unfortunately, few healthcare providers understand functional eating struggles. Therefore, medical care and services are difficult and costly to find. With rising health insurance premiums, high deductibles and out of pocket expenses, they are running out of financial resources to provide the necessary care for Lily. They receive no financial assistance from any government, state or local agency.

Lily turns 10 in September. It is amazing what this family has endured since her birth. Despite a tough battle, the light in the darkness is Lily. She has survived and while it is a struggle, she continues to fight the good fight.  She is a beautiful, happy and intelligent little girl, a living miracle on Earth. Lily's life is a testimony of faith, hope and love. This is a good family, strong in faith and hopeful for a healthy and bright future.

Thank you in advance for your contributions. This is a good cause and any little bit helps. Any donation is greatly appreciated and may God bless you for seeing the goodness in this family.  With gratitude,  Tim Hurley. 

Other Ways You Can Help:

If you can’t contribute, that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

Please send this link along to your friends and family on facebook, or linked in or just to your email contacts who you think might be interested in helping Lily.

The Indiegogo share tools on this site can help get the word out.

story:
My Story

Hi, My name is Amy, Im 29 years old and im looking for donations to help towards my fertility treatment.......now stop.....before you judge me for asking for your help.....please ready my story.... as i share my personal story with you....

I was diagnosed with PCOS (Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome) in 2005. I knew this would cause me to have fertility issues in the future. 

After several years of trying with my partner, In 2008 I was refered for fertility assisted treatment where i was put on endless drugs for 2 years but nothing worked. As anyone in a simliar position to me would understand how frustrating and heartbreaking this is so in 2011 i was allowed to be given the chance of IVF and became pregnant, I was estatic and felt that after all these years, my only dream of becoming a mom has finally come true. I had a great pregnancy and was one of he lucky ones not to suffer any normal symptoms and enjoyed everyday as i saw my bump grow. My 12 week scan showed everything was developing well and we started to tell people we were expecting and so we decided we would like to know what we were having. On 30th August, which was my partner and I 5th year anniversary, we found out we were having a little girl and we were so excited, by this time i was 16 weeks and my pregnancy was going really well with no problems. We decided we liked the name Jazmyn Elizabeth, so we chosen her name perfectly.

A few weeks later on Sunday 11th September i felt a little uncomfortable and in a little pain, shortly after my waters broke prematurely, i was rushed to hospital where my worst fears were comfirmed, i was only 18 weeks pregnant and couldnt understand why this had happened?

I was kept in over night for observation and the following day a scann was performed and there it was confirmed..... there was no water around my little girl, but i could see she was a fighter as her heartbeat was strong and i knew she was telling me i had to fight for her becuase she was still alive and to e that meant everything. I was told there is a chance the waters could rebuild and this would be enough to allow her lungs to develop and was scheduled for another appointment on Thursday 15th September. I was allowed home to bedrest, the wait was agonising as i knew she was kicking inside me letting me know not to give up on her.

On the Wednesday 14th September i began to feel unwell and rang the hospital, they were very concerned so was rushed by an Ambulance. I was kept in overnight where my last observation was of me listening to Jazmyn's heartbeat so strong that i felt that my little girl was still here and allowing me to have hope that things maybe ok, by Thursday morning i had deteriorated further and i was in and out of conciousness but i remember them checking for Jazmyn's heartbeat again to which she was still alive, i felt relieved that she was fighting with me but now i as at risk...my life was at risk as i had developed Chorioamniotsis and i was dealt the blow that if i did not end my pregnancy that i would certainly die.......inside i did at that moment. All i ever wanted to do was protect her like any mother would for their child and i was being torn to try and fight for her life yet risk my own and i knew without me she wouldnt be able to survive.....i had to make the most difficult decision along with my partner along with the words my sister had to so difficulty say "its not about the baby anymore Amy, its about you....you may die"

I was taken down to the delivery suite and a few hours later i delivered my daughter at 14:55 on Thursday 15th September 2011. I was still very poorly and with every last energy i had, i managed to hold her in my arms. Following the birth, i became severly unwell with septaceamia and was rushed to ITU, where my family and Tony were informed that i may not make it through the night and to prepare for the worst......they were told that i may only have a few hours.I was put on a ventilator to allow me to breathe after the sepsis attacked my lungs. I spent 5 days in ITU where shortly i began to recover. After 8 days in hospital i was finally allowed hospital where i was faced with the realisation that not only did i nearly die but i actually lost my daughter. I learned that i had a weak cervix following abnormal cells i had when i was 22 and had small treatment for it that i wasnt made aware that would cause me to have this. I flt empty...angry and blamed myself that i couldnt protect her....for days,weeks...i was recovering home after being on long sick leave from work yet every day went by in a blur where i mostly spent in bed apart from visitors that came and went and was allowed to go home to their families...yet where was mine?...I did everything right that a woman was supposed to yet i was the one who got punished? and thats all i could think why did this happen to me? I soon returned to work and i Christmas was on its way where my siblings got to enjoy their christmas with their children, yet my daughter was going to be still growing inside me and i felt i had nothing.

New year came and went but Jazmyn's due date was fast approaching 11th February 2012, we decided that we wanted to make her day a positive and one to be remembered for the right reasons and not the wrong....so we arranged after 6 long years we would get married and so the planning was arranged within 6 weeks. During that time the IVF clinic told me that i was allowed another go in March so to me that was better than any Honeymoon i could have. I was delighted when it worked again and felt our little girl was looking down on us. Again my pregnancy was going really well and no symptoms that we mostly dread. Upon my 8 week scan we found out were having twins!! we were very excited yet i was terribly nervous due to my weak cervix i was worried how much my body could cope. My consultant put a sutue in to support and strengthen my cervix when i was 15 weeks.I took a few weeks off work and was advised that this was going to be a high risk pregnancy but he was confident that things will be ok providing i had no stress and go on early leave at 22 weeks from work. I did all i was told and bedrested. Due to ow early twins can come, his aim was to get me past 28 weeks because this could allow them to survive outside the wormb.

Due to my pregnancy being high risk, we decided to find out what we were having so we could prepare early just incase. To our surprise we found out were having a boy and a girl!!!!! i felt that my little girl was shining down upon us and allowing us to have a completed family. The weeks flew by and we decided that our little boy was to be called Jaxon and our little girl was to be called Tamzyn. Everytime we spoke to them we kept accidently refering her as Jazmyn so we decided to rename her Jazlynne. "Jaz" - after Jazmyn and "Lynne" after my late mom who i lost when i was 14 . We felt that name was more perfect and unique.

As i was approaching 18weeks i began to feel alittle anxious but that soon passed where i could look forward to seeing my 20 week scan and the twins were doing so well that seeing them jump around felt me with joy and confidence. I left work to do as i was instructed so at 22 weeks and took bedrest leave. I enjoy relaxing at home and the thoughts for the future of having them here.

One Saturday night in July i began to have small contractions but wasnt sure it was that but knew it wasnt right and so i called the hospital who asked for me to go down to be checked out. I was 24.5 weeks pregnant, after some monitoring i was given the dreaded news i didnt think i could ever hear again... i was going into labour......how could i be? again i did everything right...did as i was told nd yet again im being put through this?

The hospital put me on drugs to try and stop my contractions but it didnt work so the only thing left to do was to give me steroid injections to help their lungs and prepare them for the outside world. I was in labour for over 2 days and by this time i was exhausted and opted to have an epidural to help allow me some time to find some strength to push. On Monday 30th July our little boy Jaxon came into the world with his little cry, hearing him cry was a relief as i knew that was a good sign, he weighed 1lb 10oz. He was rushed to Neonatal where he was stabalized and was showing good progression. Shortly after our little girl Jazlynne was born weighing 1lb 6oz and again she let out a cry and the same feeling of relief overcame me and i cried with excitement. I knew they were born alive and they were ok, they were premature but every hour that went by was a good sign. i couldnt go and see them straight away as i was on drugs to help me after the labour. 

In the middle of my IV treatment a few hours after giving birth i was given some news that our little boy Jaxon wasnt responding so well as they indicated that he had a bleed to the brain,  and that he would have little quality of life. my heart was broken all over again, they paused my treatment and i was wheeled down with all these wires and monitors to go and see him. There he was tiny but perfect....he was so beautiful with his jet black hair, we were asked if he wanted to be christened so we decided it had to be done, it gave me some peace, shortly after we had to say goodbye and turn the machine off, we held him until his heart stopped beating and promised him that Mommy and Daddy will always be with him and love him just like Jazmyn.

I felt like my world had been smashed into pieces as i was forced to go back to resume my treatment and i sat there feeling numb. .... and my mind was a blur with thoughts. I knew our little girl was also fighting and every hour  were told she was doing so well. The moment i finished treatment i had a shower and got to Neo as quick as i could and there Jazlynne was, living,breathing and alive. Se made me chuckle how she ket moving the bubble wrap off her and i thought shes going to be a madam, her hair was much lighter than Jaxons, it was a sandy colour. I watched her for aslong as i could before i felt incredibly exhausted. I decided to rest so i could gain some more energy to see and spend time with her. I was assured that she was strong and showing excellent responses to medication and that she was going to be ok despite of how early she was.

Early hours on Tuesday 31st July i was awoken to be told i needed to go to Neo as Jazlynne had detiorated. I got there as quick as my legs would take me even though i was still recovering from the epidural. I was given the bad news that the safacent in her lungs only went in her right lung and caused her left lung to blow. I heard them say that they heard her cry and new something was wrong. i felt like my whole world was collapsing as they i knew she was crying to tell them they intervened where they stabalised her and she was responding well but took a turn for the worst again where they told me there was nothing more they could do for her that i needed to decide what to do even though i knew there was only one thing that i had to be forced to do. I couldnt beleive what i had been told and thought "Not the both of them please".....

Jazlynne was put in my arms where i could hold her until she had passed away, she was so beautiful like her brother, i held her little fingers and looked at her, she was such a strong little girl that it was over an hour until she died. 

I dont even remember how i got back to the family room but all i know was that i cried myself to sleep and exhausted myself out. The following day i was discharged and i was coming home empty all over again. 

I struggled on how to deal with the twins death, all i knew was i wanted this pain to go away and for my mind just to blank it all out and the only way i felt i could cope was arranginga charity event after Shropshire SANDs coming through and helping me have th twins buried next to their sister rather than 25 miles away from our home in Bushbury. I found strength in raising money for such a good cause and allowing me to do something good in helping other parents that have suffered the lose of their baby.

I had such amazing support, incredible amount of donations that we all managed to raise over £5,500. Something that i never thought i could achieve as well as raise awareness, i met truely inspirational people along the way and found som comfort from it all.

In December i felt i was ready to have another IVF treatment but unfortunatley it didnt work, i felt like i was suffering another lose even though it wasnt. I decided that i needed to take time out and concentrate on getting my mind and body healthy so took cycling up along with bootcamp. 

Due to my history of a weak cervix i discussed with my consultant that i needed something more assuring after reasearching about a TAC, where i would have a C-section like operation that would allow me to 95% to carry full term. i decided this was my best option as i wasnt ready to give up on trying to have a rainbow baby. After 4 months i finally was able to have the operation. 7 weeks later i had another go on IVF with the egg that i have in storage...this time i was in strong hope this would work, i felt i did everything i could to allow me to conceive successfully.....again unfortunatley it didnt work and i took it really bad where i even contemplated on giving up and facing the fact i would never have a baby of my own. I looked at my 7 inch scar on my stomach and remembered why i had this operation, how far ive come in life. i decided i couldnt wait another 6 months as that was sometimes as painful as a negative pregnancy test so i researched and looked into Egg Sharing programme where i am able to receive IVF at a reduced cost i i could donate half of my eggs to a recipient. I feel this is a perfect idea to not only helping someone out there but also another chance of maybe conceiving again. 

Liverpool Womens Hospital have an excellent pregnancy care plan ready and waiting for me. Shrewsbury Clinic are fantastic but i need to be a rainbow mommy before 2013 is out so i can have hope that next year when i turn 30 that i will eventually have what ive always dreamed of.

I am very proud of all my babies and i will forever be their mommy.

 

I know this is a big ask and some may even think im being cheeky but i have alot of supportive people who are willing to help me do this.

Please help me...........

 

Thank You Amy xxx

In Memory of Jazmyn....Jaxon....Jazlynne xxx

We felt that name was more perfect and unique.
As i was approaching 18weeks i began to feel alittle anxious but that soon passed where i could look forward to seeing my 20 week scan and the twins were doing so well that seeing them jump around felt me with joy and confidence. I left work to do as i was instructed so at 22 weeks and took bedrest leave. I enjoy relaxing at home and the thoughts for the future of having them here.
One Saturday night in July i began to have small contractions but wasnt sure it was that but knew it wasnt right and so i called the hospital who asked for me to go down to be checked out. I was 24.5 weeks pregnant, after some monitoring i was given the dreaded news i didnt think i could ever hear again... i was going into labour......how could i be? again i did everything right...did as i was told nd yet again im being put through this?
The hospital put me on drugs to try and stop my contractions but it didnt work so the only thing left to do was to give me steroid injections to help their lungs and prepare them for the outside world. I was in labour for over 2 days and by this time i was exhausted and opted to have an epidural to help allow me some time to find some strength to push. On Monday 30th July our little boy Jaxon came into the world with his little cry, hearing him cry was a relief as i knew that was a good sign, he weighed 1lb 10oz. He was rushed to Neonatal where he was stabalized and was showing good progression. Shortly after our little girl Jazlynne was born weighing 1lb 6oz and again she let out a cry and the same feeling of relief overcame me and i cried with excitement. I knew they were born alive and they were ok, they were premature but every hour that went by was a good sign. i couldnt go and see them straight away as i was on drugs to help me after the labour. 
In the middle of my IV treatment a few hours after giving birth i was given some news that our little boy Jaxon wasnt responding so well as they indicated that he had a bleed to the brain,  and that he would have little quality of life. my heart was broken all over again, they paused my treatment and i was wheeled down with all these wires and monitors to go and see him. There he was tiny but perfect....he was so beautiful with his jet black hair, we were asked if he wanted to be christened so we decided it had to be done, it gave me some peace, shortly after we had to say goodbye and turn the machine off, we held him until his heart stopped beating and promised him that Mommy and Daddy will always be with him and love him just like Jazmyn.
I felt like my world had been smashed into pieces as i was forced to go back to resume my treatment and i sat there feeling numb. .... and my mind was a blur with thoughts. I knew our little girl was also fighting and every hour  were told she was doing so well. The moment i finished treatment i had a shower and got to Neo as quick as i could and there Jazlynne was, living,breathing and alive. Se made me chuckle how she ket moving the bubble wrap off her and i thought shes going to be a madam, her hair was much lighter than Jaxons, it was a sandy colour. I watched her for aslong as i could before i felt incredibly exhausted. I decided to rest so i could gain some more energy to see and spend time with her. I was assured that she was strong and showing excellent responses to medication and that she was going to be ok despite of how early she was.
Early hours on Tuesday 31st July i was awoken to be told i needed to go to Neo as Jazlynne had detiorated. I got there as quick as my legs would take me even though i was still recovering from the epidural. I was given the bad news that the safacent in her lungs only went in her right lung and caused her left lung to blow. I heard them say that they heard her cry and new something was wrong. i felt like my whole world was collapsing as they i knew she was crying to tell them they intervened where they stabalised her and she was responding well but took a turn for the worst again where they told me there was nothing more they could do for her that i needed to decide what to do even though i knew there was only one thing that i had to be forced to do. I couldnt beleive what i had been told and thought "Not the both of them please".....
Jazlynne was put in my arms where i could hold her until she had passed away, she was so beautiful like her brother, i held her little fingers and looked at her, she was such a strong little girl that it was over an hour until she died. 
I dont even remember how i got back to the family room but all i know was that i cried myself to sleep and exhausted myself out. The following day i was discharged and i was coming home empty all over again. 
I struggled on how to deal with the twins death, all i knew was i wanted this pain to go away and for my mind just to blank it all out and the only way i felt i could cope was arranginga charity event after Shropshire SANDs coming through and helping me have th twins buried next to their sister rather than 25 miles away from our home in Bushbury. I found strength in raising money for such a good cause and allowing me to do something good in helping other parents that have suffered the lose of their baby.
I had such amazing support, incredible amount of donations that we all managed to raise over £5,500. Something that i never thought i could achieve as well as raise awareness, i met truely inspirational people along the way and found som comfort from it all.
In December i felt i was ready to have another IVF treatment but unfortunatley it didnt work, i felt like i was suffering another lose even though it wasnt. I decided that i needed to take time out and concentrate on getting my mind and body healthy so took cycling up along with bootcamp. 
Due to my history of a weak cervix i discussed with my consultant that i needed something more assuring after reasearching about a TAC, where i would have a C-section like operation that would allow me to 95% to carry full term. i decided this was my best option as i wasnt ready to give up on trying to have a rainbow baby. After 4 months i finally was able to have the operation. 7 weeks later i had another go on IVF with the egg that i have in storage...this time i was in strong hope this would work, i felt i did everything i could to allow me to conceive successfully.....again unfortunatley it didnt work and i took it really bad where i even contemplated on giving up and facing the fact i would never have a baby of my own. I looked at my 7 inch scar on my stomach and remembered why i had this operation, how far ive come in life. i decided i couldnt wait another 6 months as that was sometimes as painful as a negative pregnancy test so i researched and looked into Egg Sharing programme where i am able to receive IVF at a reduced cost i i could donate half of my eggs to a recipient. I feel this is a perfect idea to not only helping someone out there but also another chance of maybe conceiving again. 
Liverpool Womens Hospital have an excellent pregnancy care plan ready and waiting for me. Shrewsbury Clinic are fantastic but i need to be a rainbow mommy before 2013 is out so i can have hope that next year when i turn 30 that i will eventually have what ive always dreamed of.
I am very proud of all my babies and i will forever be their mommy.
 
I know this is a big ask and some may even think im being cheeky but i have alot of supportive people who are willing to help me do this.
Please help me...........
 
Thank You Amy xxx
In Memory of Jazmyn....Jaxon....Jazlynne xxx

story:
Short Summary

About a month ago, Ivan was in a terrible car accident in Rakitovo, Bulgaria.

He has been in the hospital in Plovdiv ever since, and doctors have been fighting to keep him alive.  Recently, the doctors told his parents that he needs a shunt (implant in Bulgarian) to regulate the intracranial pressure (ICP) in his brain.  Until now, this fluid has been collected through the use of tubes and bags in the hospital.  This shunt would be able to help regulate his ICP for the next two to three years while he heals.   

All this time, health insurance has been taking care of Ivan's needs, but this shunt is not covered. His parents are currently unemployed.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $3000 to cover the cost of the shunt (about $2800) and the administrative costs of getting your generous donations to Bulgaria. 
 
Anyone who donates will receive the eternal gratitude of Ivan's family.  Anyone who donates in excess of $25 will receive an individual thank-you from a Peace Corps Volunteer on a beautiful postcard from Plovdiv.  We apologize for not being able to offer more, but our own resources are limited. 

The Impact

This project will both save Ivan's life and allow him to slowly return to health and home.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign with your friends on social networks such as Facebook and Twitter.
 
You can also help by sending your prayers, positive thoughts, left-over good karma, etc.

story:
I hope that by contributing to my cause, you will help inspire my cousin to fight leukemia and live. 

About her disease: http://www.cancer.org/cancer/leukemia-acutemyel... 

In the past six months, three of my family members in the Philippines have been affected by cancer. First, my grandmother Lola Letty passed away on October 2013 by pancreatic cancer. Then, my great aunt Lola Precy who died of stage four breast cancer this March 2014. Now, my family just found out that my 12 year old cousin Christine has acute Leukemia, which is a cancer of the blood.

After finding out the news, I’ve been doing some research on the disease and her type of Leukemia actually spreads rapidly, which is why I want my family in the Philippines to have her treated, no matter what the cost. In order to save her, she either needs a bone marrow transplant or chemotherapy--which the doctors already confirmed. I've been browsing around for how much the treatments cost and I've mostly seen that costs go up to around $60,000 to $250,000 (for a bone marrow transplant). Looking at her parents’, my family, and my extended family’s financial situation, it is extremely difficult to pay for her upcoming medical bills, even if all of our family contributed.  I remember that my parents, and my relatives from Australia spent all of our savings in prolonging my grandmother’s life on morphine, blood transfusions, and other medical bills for her cancer treatment. When we thought that it was all over, we are now faced with an even more difficult situation, but with very little amount to contribute

If you are reading this, please have it in your heart to help out and donate. Her parents, are modest hard working people, but they simply cannot afford her medical bills. Their family situation right now is that Tita Naida (my aunt) is left in the Philippines with the kids, including Christine, while Tito Vince (my uncle) is back from working in Saudi Arabia with his family.

It was only after all these instances of cancer did I realize how blessed I was to have the opportunity to have the privileges of  living in America where people have access to advanced medical technology and health care. And since I am here, I would like to help and give back to my family who doesn't have as much opportunities as I have, which is why I am creating this fund for my 12 year old cousin who still has so many things to achieve in her lifetime, dreams to fulfill for herself and her siblings. All of the money that I receive from this donation will go to her treatment.


About Christine:

Since my family can only come back every 4-5 years to the Philippines, I rarely get to see or know my cousins. But, when I returned to Philippines summer 2013, Christine and the rest of our cousins greeted us warmly, as if we were always there. I remember her telling me about things she would like to do when she grows up, especially the part where she told me that she’d like to help her parents especially her mom in the future because she worked so hard, but had little pay to support her kids. Like me, Christine wants to give back to family. 

In addition, when I took a walk with my cousins, we stopped by their house and I was really surprised that all my cousins in the Philippines lived in a one bedroom “hut” with no electricity, while I took my house for granted. Christine, along with the rest of my cousins were kind, welcoming, and humble, despite what little they had.

Please donate to my cause and share around the internet. All of the money that I will receive from this campaign will be for her treatment.  I’m sure that she will appreciate the help that she receives. And I will be very grateful even if you could re-share my cause. Thank you so much!

If you donate, you can email me at rikkaguillen@gmail.com if you would like updates--and if my relatives in the Philippines could send them--pictures/ videos of Christine.

story:
PAULA METHOD - WHAT ARE THE RING-MUSCLES

There is a system of muscles in the human body that is the source of life's fundamental process. These are the Ring Muscles, also known as sphincters. There are Ring Muscles in every part of our body, both internally and externally and it is their coordinated and harmonious contraction and relaxation that initiates breathing, digestion, circulation, elimination, and all muscular motion.

Paula Garbourg, the developer of The Paula Method explains that the basic principle behind her method of self-healing is the way the Ring Muscles function; their importance in everyday life, and the problems that can result when they fail to work together properly. Based on decades of experience, Paula Garbourg developed a series of exercises that will allow you to take advantage of this revolutionary approach to self-healing and and get cured or be relieved from most common ailments. 

 

Paula Garbourg observed that when the Ring Muscles all work together, we are in good health. When the Ring Muscles do not work together, illness and imbalance result. By improving the functioning of these muscles, she discovered, we can free ourselves of various pains and health problems. 

being that each body is different, there are no particular exercises for any given ailment and it might take several exercises to find the most functional exercise that will initiate the chain reaction and will result in body balance, healing the ailing part.

In Israel where Paula Garbourg made the discovery and developed her method, all HMOs and insurance companies are recognizing the Paula Method and there are over 100 certified practitioners that direct their patients to the right exercises that will better work for them.


WHO WILL BENEFIT FROM THE PAULA METHOD

People who are suffering from the most common ailments, are seeking a
natural healing solution rather then traditional medicine, and
individuals experiencing:

Asthma, Incontinence, Backache, Bed-wetting, Prolapse of the Uterus, Retardation, Depression, Digestive problems, Arthritis, Stress and the list goes on.


PRACTITIONERS WILL NOW BE AVAILABLE AT YOUR HOME...

While in Israel certified practitioners of the Paula Method are
providing one on one sessions to patients seeking healing for their
ailments, there are none at the moment elsewhere in the world. We've come up
with a solution to help more people suffering from ailments with our
Ring Muscles exercises.

Have a certified practitioner at YOUR HOME! 

Haya Garbourg and her staff are now available to determine which exercise will best work for you according to your body' reaction to each exercise. 


HOW IT WORKS...

Haya will contact you through an online secured video system and will demonstrate and teach you a series of exercises while observing your body's reaction. Several exercises may be required until the right combination of exercises will be determined. 

All you need is high speed Internet connection and a computer with a webcam. Set the computer or portable device on a desk near your bed. Make sure to position the screen so you will be able to see and hear the instructions while lying in bed with the camera directed to you. 

Each session will last 50 minutes. For your benefit you should repeat the exercises daily (or as often as you wish) on your own. Exercises have varied effects on different people / bodies and Haya will determine which exercise better. Session frequency depends entirely on your preference. Some patients require constant observation to help them focus, and others require less. 


MEDICAL TESTIMONIAL

Prof. Y. Goldhammer,

Head of Neurology Department, Shiba Hospital, Israel.

Paula Garbourg's Gymnastics has more than once succeeded where a variety of medical treatments have failed. It is often difficult to explain the beneficial results. The public would do well to make its acquaintance. 


Dr. H. Tipereth

Specialist in Gynecology and Obstetrics

I personally did these exercises for relief of my asthma - of which Thank God I am now free - and other ailments from which I was suffering. I know that many people with ailments like prolapse of genital organs, prolapse of the discs of the vertebrae column, asthma, headaches, partial palsies after C.V.A or other forms of muscular troubles like E.P. were enormously aided by Paula's exercises.


Prof. Bruce Pomerantz,

MD/PHD, University of Toronto. 

"In our attempts to have patients take responsibility for their own health, and to reduce the use of dangerous drugs and surgery, [Paula Garbourg's Ring Muscle] exercises seem to be most appropriate."


A. Yaroslavsky

M.D. Pediatrician. 

The principle of Sphincter-Gymnastics is based on Paula Garbourg's observation that in the healthy body all the sphincters work together as one unit. In the healthy body all the sphincters contract and relax simultaneously, activating the respiratory system, gastrointestinal system and the urogenital system. It is possible to induce the activity of involuntary sphincters by the voluntary ones and activate the malfunctioning area by the healthy one. There are a lot of cases that were helped by this method of "Sphincter Gymnastics." Paula Garbourg has an experience of over forty years. 

   

Dr. M. Levy

Medical Director - Complementary Medicine, Clalit HMO 

Dear Haya, 

Thank you for visiting our center.

As you realized we offer our Health Insurance members a variety of alternative (complimentary) healing methods, including the Ring Muscles techniques of Paula Garbourg, known here as the Paula MethodT. 

Most of the patients are referred to the Paula MethodT practitioners through our Physicians, as an "alternative remedy" to the conventional medical solutions (drugs). 

Patients with the following ailments are traditionally referred to Paula Method practitioners: 

Asthma, Headaches Backache, Urinary and fecal incontinence, Pregnancy and preparation for delivery, Prolapsed uterus, urinary bladder and others.

We look forward your collaboration with our institute and look forward your next visit.


PATIENT COMMENTS

Haya changed my life.

I felt the change immediately after the first treatment. I felt much better - I got my appetite back and I felt more energetic and vital. things got better from day to day. Haya was there for me for everything I needed. she was always looking for the right combination of exercises that would fit me the best. she taught me how to use the Paula Method technique and make it a part of my life. this is the best part about the technique - you can do it anytime anywhere.

it's not only the technique but also Haya herself - she is so optimistic and full of life - she gives you the feeling that everything is going to be ok.

I keep using the technique - even for a few minutes every day - and I can still feel the change. things are getting better and better. I know that I can call Haya any time - she is always there for me.

Thank you so much Haya for everything !!!

Adi


HOW WILL YOUR FUNDING HELP US?

1. spread the word.

We are planning a massive internet campaign to reach those who seek natural healing solution,

2. Open a studio in Tel Aviv and purchase broadcasting equipment

 3. Obtain a quality secured video platform


THE TEAM

              

Haya Garbourg - head practitioner. Certified by the founder Paula         Garbourg to practice and teach the Paula Method with 30 years                     experiance, heading the Paula Garburg Institute.

David Garbourg - CEO. Marketing and Management experiance spanning over 40 yars in Israel and the US.  Paioneer in online Marketing and familiar (first hand) with the Paula Method.

Nir schwarz - Technology expert 

Hana Osherov - Customer Service

Sharon Zur - Media specialist


WHY YOU CAN TRUST US TO DELIVER

Books and DVDs are already printed and will be shipped from Florida

Haya Garbourg and her team is ready to start multi-language service

The secured broadcasting technology is available

Online advertising such as Google Adword will be used to spread the word... 

Our mission is to promote the Paula Method outside Israel and help those needing assistance anywhere in the world.


FAQ

Q. Do I need instruments?

A. No. no need for any instrument

Q. Do I need to lie in bed to do the exercises?

A. You can exercise in bed, while sitting by the computer or TV. You can even do certain exercises while driving

Q. How often should I exercise?

A. We recommend 30 minutes daily. Eventually your body will initiate certain moves / exercises on its own.

Q. How long will it take for the body to heal?

A. Time varies from one body to other and the frequency of doing the exercises. Also the type of ailment is a factor. 

Q. Are the exercise sessions done in groups?

A. No, the exercises are done in person, one patient at the time, since each body reacts differently to any exercise.

Q. Does the Paula Method involves stretching or massage?

A. No. The exercises are done by the patient only! The practitioner will demonstrate the exercise, watch the patient and correct when necessary and observe the body' reaction, before turning to another exercise.

Q. How come the Paula Method is known only in Israel?

A. The founder Paula Garbourg lived in Israel where she trained and certified new practitioners. Patients were referred by physicians or by word of mouth. While many in Israel turns to the practitioner, there are no certified practitioners worldwide to turn to.

Q. What is needed for a remote practitioner session?

A. A computer (preferably laptop) viewable from bed wile laying and Web Camera pointing to the bed. That's all that is required. Your Practitioner will demonstrate the execises for you to follow, observed and guided by the Practitioner

Q. Can the book and DVD be sufficient?

A. The book is offering an in-depth explanation of the Paula Method and the right way to practice it. The DVD provide description of the right way to exercise. Some get results from exercising as described in the book, others prefers to get live guidance guidance, for faster results, short or long term


SELECT A PERK

$ 35 Get acquainted 

Book and DVD 

The Secret of the Ring Muscles by Paula Garbourg

and DVD with Haya Garbourg

Free US Shipping (International Shipping add $10)


$119 Get the feel

Book & DVD + a remote sessions 

The Secret of the Ring Muscles by Paula Garbourg

and DVD with Haya Garbourg

+ get a session with Haya and her team, 50 minutes.

Free US Shipping (International Shipping add $10)



$249 Gateway to healing

Book & DVD + 3 remote sessions 

The Secret of the Ring Muscles by Paula Garbourg                                               

and DVD with Haya Garbourg

+ get 3 sessions with Haya and her team, 50 minutes each.

Free US Shipping (International Shipping add $10)


$4900 GO LIVE! 

We will fly you to our clinic in Tel Aviv, the city that never stops, for 5 personal healing sessions with Haya Garbourg. Treat will include return flight to Tel Aviv, 7 nights first class accommodation with breakfast and 2 day tours to Jerusalem and Galilee.
